metadata.case_name: Smt. Prabhawati Devi v. Dr. Pritam Kaur

facts.text: The appellant is a tenant occupying premises belonging to the respondent.

The respondent applied to the District Magistrate, Dehradun (Rent Controller), under S. 3 of the U.P. Temporary Control of Rent and Eviction Act, 1947 for permission to sue the appellant for eviction.
Permission was granted by the Rent Controller.
Appellant filed revision to the Commissioner, Meerut Division, who affirmed the Rent Controller's order on March 30, 1965 in revision No. 13.
Appellant filed revision to the State Government on April 2, 1965; State Government passed stay order pending consideration.
Appellant sent copy of revision petition to Minister for Irrigation, who forwarded it noting appellant is very old tenant.
State Government allowed the revision on June 14, 1966, revoking permission under S.3, stating expedient in ends of justice.
Respondent filed writ under Art. 226 before Allahabad High Court challenging State Government order.
High Court allowed petition on February 28, 1967, quashed State Government order dated 14-6-1966, directed rehearing under S.7-F according to law, with costs.
On February 29, 1967 (next day), respondent filed suit for eviction of appellant.
Ramesh Puri wrote letter on May 16, 1966 to Minister for Food and Civil Supplies recommending appellant's case.
State Government dismissed revision as infructuous due to institution of civil suit, relying on High Court decision.
Appellant filed writ petition before Allahabad High Court challenging State Government dismissal; High Court dismissed, holding stay lapsed and revision infructuous.
Appeal by special leave to Supreme Court from High Court judgment dated February 5, 1971 in Special Appeal No. 1116 of 1969.

legal_issues.text: Whether the revision petition before the State Government became infructuous upon institution of the eviction suit filed by respondent immediately after High Court directed rehearing.
Whether the stay order passed by State Government revived upon High Court setting aside its order and directing rehearing.

petitioner_arguments.text: High Court order setting aside State Government order and directing rehearing revived the interim stay order; suit was premature and cannot frustrate High Court direction.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Bankim Chandra v. Chandi Prasad (Patna HC); Tavvale Veeraswami v. Pulim Ramanna (Madras HC); Saranatha Aiyangar v. Muthiah Mooppanar (Madras HC); Sushila Bali Dasi v. Guest Keen Williams Ltd. (Calcutta HC)

respondent_arguments.text: Revision petition became infructuous upon institution of suit for eviction, as per High Court decisions; State Government competent to dismiss on that ground.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Bhagwan Das v. Paras Nath; Mohammad Ismail v. Nanney Lal

court_reasoning.text: No party can frustrate court decision by trickery; High Court order required State Government to decide afresh on permission, precluding respondent from filing suit till then; suit premature and does not bar State Government from proceeding.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Respondent cannot obstruct implementation of direction given at her instance.

court_reasoning.text: Powers under Act exercised judicially; criticized multi-tier executive process causing prolonged litigation; noted extraneous influences like ministerial notes.
court_reasoning.key_observation: State Government order lacked reasons, influenced by irrelevant considerations.

court_reasoning.text: No need to decide revival of stay, as appeal succeeds on broader ground of prematurity.
court_reasoning.key_observation: High Court direction implies no suit till revision disposed.

holdings.text: Suit filed by respondent was premature and does not render revision infructuous; State Government must dispose of revision according to law.

precedents_cited.relevance: Suit after permission not affected by later S.7-F order
Suit after permission not affected by later S.7-F order

statutes_cited.name: U.P. Temporary Control of Rent and Eviction Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Permission for eviction required; revision to Commissioner and State Government

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Writ petition challenging State Government order

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; High Court order dismissing writ and State Government order dismissing revision set aside; State Government directed to restore and dispose revision within four months; respondent may seek stay of suit proceedings.
outcome.relief_granted: Restoration and expeditious disposal of revision petition; liberty to stay suit.

key_quotes.text: "No party to a litigation can be permitted to frustrate the decision rendered by having recourse to trickery."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on prematurity of suit

key_quotes.text: "The true effect of the order made by the High Court in the writ petition was that the question whether the respondent should be permitted to file a suit for ejectment of the appellant or not must be gone into and decided afresh by the State Government."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains implication of High Court direction

key_quotes.text: "One would search this order in vain for the reason that persuaded the State Government to allow the revision petition. Not a single reason is given."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Critique of State Government order lacking reasons
